data.text:
I was at the cinema last evening settling into Gainsbourg: Vie H√©ro√Øque, the biopic of the legendary French singer-songwriter, when I suddenly found myself near choking on my honey-roasted peanuts. To my complete and utter surprise, there on the screen playing Serge Gainsbourg‚Äôs first wife was my very own cousin! Frantically struggling to google the movie‚Äôs cast on my blackberry, it took everything in me not to squeal from excitement when I saw my family name on the list. I can only conclude, however, that like most French families, mine has serious communication issues.

With the discovery of my cousin‚Äôs sudden leap into mainstream French cinema, I was naturally engrossed in the film already. But I also knew that the two characters which had lured me away from my laptop to come and see the film in the first place, were about to make an appearance. Bardot and Birkin‚Äì two of the most beautiful and iconic actresses that I have aspired to for their style and spirit ever since I first laid eyes on their photographs. When I visit the hairdresser for my seasonal make-over, I‚Äôll either be clutching a tear-out of Brigitte Bardot‚Äôs romantic and tousled boudoir coiffe or Jane Birkin‚Äôs signature hipster bangs. These two women also happened to be the great loves of Serge Gainsbourg.

For those of you asking who the heck is Serge Gainsbourg? Tut tut!

He is basically the French John Lennon.

Bardot

Bardot fell for Gainsbourg while she was still married to notorious playboy Gunther Sachs. R√©gine, a singer and infamous Parisian nightclub owner, recalls their passionate affair. ‚ÄúSerge and Bardot were in my kitchen all the time because she didn‚Äôt want to go to restaurants. She was always laughing with him, and he was thrilled to be with her, such a beautiful woman.‚Äù

When he met her, Bardot‚Äôs film career was slowing down and he helped her move into music. Together, they recorded ‚ÄúJe T‚ÄôAime‚Ä¶ Moi Non Plus,‚Äù which featured the sounds of Brigitte‚Äôs explicit sexual moaning. She begged him not to release it in fear of exposing their affair to her husband and Gainsbourg later released it with Jane Birkin‚Äôs vocals instead. The song was banned in most European countries.

***

Birkin

When Bardot returned to her husband, 4o-year old Serge fell for the beautiful 22-year-old Jane Birkin. The British actress whose style evoked the swinging sixties and provocative French superstar, together, were a force of nature on the Paris social scene. Castel‚Äôs nightclub, which still exists on the Rue Princesse on the Left Bank, set the scene for many of their alcohol-fuelled theatricals. One night, Serge emptied the basket that she carried as a handbag and threw it onto the ground. Absurdly, she retaliated by throwing a custard pie in his face. After he stormed out, she raced past him towards the Seine and as soon as she saw him catch up to her, she flung herself into the city‚Äôs river to later be rescued by firemen. The lovers then strolled arm in arm back to their decadent home on Rue de Verneuil.

Birkin on Bardot

Both Serge and Jane were known to be outrageously jealous lovers. When Jane made a movie with Bardot, while Serge felt threatened by the film‚Äôs director, Jane confessed, ‚ÄúI wanted to see every portion of her [Bardot‚Äôs] body to see if she was as beautiful as I thought she was, and she is. Checked from head to toe by me. There‚Äôs not one fault in the woman.‚Äù

The Story behind the Birkin Bag

On an Air France flight from Paris to London, Jane Birkin pulled her Herm√®s date book out of her bag and all her papers fell on the floor. She complained to the passenger sitting next to her that the book should have pockets. That passenger was the chairman of Herm√®s, Jean-Louis Dumas, and after hearing her complain he created the Birkin bag.

Charlotte Gainsbourg

‚ÄúIf he [Serge] had seen me giving birth to Charlotte, it‚Äôs possible he never would have slept with me again.‚Äù (Jane Birkin)

In 1971 Birkin gave birth to their daughter, Charlotte. She was constantly with her parents, even at nightclubs when she was still small enough to fit in Jane‚Äôs infamous baskets that she used as handbags (see images above). At the age of thirteen, she did a duet with her father called ‚ÄòLemon Incest‚Äô. The song included the lyrics, ‚Äúthe love that we will never make.‚Äù It shocked the nation and sparked outrage but Charlotte still insists today that it was ‚Äúa pure love song from father to daughter‚Äù and speaks fondly of Gainsbourg, who died of a heart attack in 1991.

‚ÄúEvery time I get into a taxi [in Paris] I hear a story about my father, because he used to take taxis all day long and [the drivers] tell me how sweet he was.‚Äù

Charlotte is today a renowned actress in both Hollywood and independent cinema, not to mention, she‚Äôs practically royalty in France.

What is it about Gainsbourg?

Serge Gainsbourg was not blessed with good looks. So how did he manage to seduce some of the worlds most beautiful women?

‚ÄúI never actually had a relationship with him,‚Äù says Marianne Faithfull, who first met Serge in 1965. ‚ÄúBut I sometimes wish I had. You could tell that anyone who slept with him would come away very satisfied indeed. Ha ha! He had a wonderful aura of quiet confidence around him, an odd mixture of shyness and arrogance.‚Äù

Some might suggest that it was Gainsbourg‚Äôs women that made his career. Truthfully, his records did not attract as much attention as they did when women started to cover his songs. Brigitte Bardot, Juliette Gr√©co, Catherine Deneuve, Isabelle Adjani, Marianne Faithfull and Vanessa Paradis all had hits with the songwriter‚Äì several of which he had affairs with.

‚ÄúSerge liked to surround himself with women,‚Äù says Jane Birkin,‚ÄùHe was insecure about his looks and felt validated by their attentions.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe was feeling like he was not a beautiful man, but inside he was a beautiful man, and his charm was more important. And when a man like that has success, they start to have beautiful women.‚Äù

(R√©gine, friend of Gainsbourg)

Messy Nessy recommends you see Gainsbourg: La Vie Heroique
